title: Modified Rankin Scale for Neurologic Disability
description: Measures the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities of people who have suffered a stroke or other causes of neurological disability

parameters.name: functional_status
parameters.description: Patient's current functional status and level of independence

result.name: mrs_score
result.description: Modified Rankin Scale score for neurologic disability assessment

ranges.interpretation: Perfect health without symptoms. Complete functional independence.

ranges.description: Able to carry out all usual duties and activities
ranges.interpretation: No significant disability despite symptoms. Can perform all usual duties and activities.

ranges.description: Unable to carry out all previous activities but can look after own affairs
ranges.interpretation: Slight disability. Unable to carry out all previous activities but able to look after own affairs without assistance.

ranges.description: Requires some help but able to walk unassisted
ranges.interpretation: Moderate disability. Requires some help but able to walk unassisted.

ranges.description: Unable to attend to bodily needs without assistance and unable to walk unassisted
ranges.interpretation: Moderately severe disability. Unable to attend to own bodily needs without assistance and unable to walk unassisted.

ranges.description: Bedridden, incontinent and requiring constant nursing care
ranges.interpretation: Severe disability. Bedridden, incontinent and requiring constant nursing care and attention.

references: Rankin J. Cerebral vascular accidents in patients over the age of 60. II. Prognosis. Scott Med J. 1957 Jul;2(7):200-15. doi: 10.1177/003693305700200704.
Warlow C, Dennis M, van Gijn J, et al. Stroke: A Practical Guide to Management. Oxford: Blackwell Scientific Publications; 2001.

Bruno A, Shah N, Lin C, Close B, Hess DC, Davis K, Baute V, Switzer JA, Waller JL, Nichols FT. Improving modified Rankin Scale assessment with a simplified questionnaire. Stroke. 2010 May;41(5):1048-50. doi: 10.1161/STROKEAHA.109.571562.

Banks JL, Marotta CA. Outcomes validity and reliability of the modified Rankin scale: implications for stroke clinical trials: a literature review and synthesis. Stroke. 2007 Mar;38(3):1091-6. doi: 10.1161/01.STR.0000258355.23810.c6.
formula: Single ordinal scale from 0-6: 0 = No symptoms, 1 = No significant disability, 2 = Slight disability, 3 = Moderate disability, 4 = Moderately severe disability, 5 = Severe disability, 6 = Dead.
notes: Most widely used outcome scale in acute stroke trials and clinical practice
Originally developed by John Rankin in 1957, modified by Charles Warlow in 1980s
Provides common language for describing degree of disability after neurological events
Assessment should use standardized interview to reduce subjectivity
Consider patient's ability to work, maintain hobbies, social connections, and independence in ADLs
Scores 3-5 represent increasing levels of dependence
Inter-rater reliability improved with structured interview protocols
Important predictor of quality of life and healthcare resource utilization
Used to determine eligibility for stroke interventions and rehabilitation services
Key endpoint in stroke clinical trials and quality improvement initiatives
